facts.text: Smt. Paramajit Kaur, prosecutrix, a young girl under 16 years of age, went out in the evening of November 26, 1967 to ease herself.
Surjit Kaur and Phullan met her and induced her to visit Dalip Singh's house to be given nice clothes.
At Dalip Singh's house, she was handed over to him, who threatened her with a knife and took her to appellant Gurcharan Singh's baithak.
Appellant threatened Paramjit Kaur with a pistol and took her to his fields to the tube-well room where he committed rape on her twice.
Sanjha Ram arrived, appellant left her in his custody, Sanjha Ram committed rape on her.
Appellant returned with bedding and food, both committed rape on her the whole night.
On following morning, appellant left her with Sanjha Ram to find a customer; Sanjha Ram took her to sugarcane field by day and raped her there too.

Prosecutrix did not return home; uncle Shingara Singh, father Avtar Singh searched; FIR lodged on November 29, 1967 by Shingara Singh under ss. 363/366 IPC suspecting Dalip Singh, Trilok Singh, Surjit Kaur, Gurcharan Singh and his wife.

On November 29, Anokhi Singh (PW 6) informed Col. Harnam Singh (PW 4) of presence in appellant's sugarcane field; group found Paramjit Kaur and Sanjha Ram there; Sanjha Ram tried to escape but secured; prosecutrix narrated story.
Taken to police station Ladwa, met SI Balwant Singh who recorded statements.

Prosecutrix medically examined by Dr. K. Kaushalya at 7 p.m. on November 29; found tear on hymen which bled, opinion rape 3-4 days prior, healing process; age 15-16 years via X-ray by Dr. L.R. Sardana.
Sessions Judge, Karnal convicted Gurcharan Singh under ss. 366 and 376 IPC (3 years RI and 4 years RI + fine); acquitted Phullan and Surjit Kaur; convicted Sanjha Ram and Dalip Singh.
Punjab Haryana High Court upheld convictions and sentences in Criminal Appeal No. 633 of 1968 on November 28, 1968.
Prosecutrix PW 3 narrated story straightforwardly; had visited appellant's house before; denied animosity or going voluntarily.

Appellant pleaded alibi: at Rohtak for sister's marriage Nov 23-25, returned for son's medical on 26-27; witness Shankar Dass supported but courts rejected as he could have returned by evening of 26th.
Appellant inconsistent age: 30-32 in 1963 application, 45 in medical cert Dec 1967, 50 in s.342 statement.
Appellant pleaded incapable of intercourse, belied by medical exam.
Enmity alleged between Harnam Singh and appellant.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant committed kidnapping/abduction under s.366 IPC.
Whether rape under s.376 IPC was committed, considering medical evidence and lack of violence marks.
Whether conviction can be based on solitary uncorroborated testimony of prosecutrix.

petitioner_arguments.text: Kidnapping/abduction complete when induced by two ladies; appellant's taking her later not kidnapping/abduction under s.366 IPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State v. Gopichand (AIR 1961 Bom 282); ss.361,362 IPC

petitioner_arguments.text: No rape committed; medical evidence shows no marks of violence; no penetration.
Solitary statement of prosecutrix without corroboration in material particulars insufficient for conviction.
Alibi: appellant at Rohtak for marriage and son's medical.
Enmity with Harnam Singh leading to false implication.

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution story as narrated by prosecutrix reliable; corroborated by recovery, medical evidence, witnesses.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant's act of threatening with pistol and taking to fields constitutes abduction under s.362 IPC; kidnapping from guardianship not applicable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gopichand case inapplicable as no prior kidnapping from lawful custody.

court_reasoning.text: Rape established under s.375 fifthly for girl under 16; consent immaterial; penetration sufficient; no marks of violence irrelevant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Medical evidence supports rape 3-4 days prior.

court_reasoning.text: Prosecutrix not accomplice; rule of prudence requires corroboration but can be dispensed if safe; here corroborated by recovery from appellant's field, immediate complaint to Harnam Singh, medical evidence, broken bangles.
Alibi rejected; could have returned to village by evening of Nov 26.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant's inconsistent ages and failed impotence plea.

court_reasoning.text: Age under 16 confirmed by school headmaster, mother, medical/X-ray; not challenged in High Court.

holdings.text: Conviction under ss.366 and 376 IPC proper; abduction by force/threat; rape on minor under 16 proved.
Testimony of prosecutrix can sustain conviction with corroboration, which is present.

precedents_cited.relevance: Inapplicable as no kidnapping from lawful custody.
Prosecutrix not accomplice; corroboration rule of prudence, not law; can dispense if safe.
English law on corroboration in sexual offences same as India.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sidheswar Ganguly v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Corroborative evidence must lend assurance to prosecutrix's testimony.

precedents_cited.case_name: Janardan Tewari v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Evidence of prosecutrix must be corroborated to connect accused.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences of kidnapping/abduction, wrongful confinement, rape; definitions applied to convict appellant.

outcome.summary: Appeal against conviction and sentence under ss.366 and 376 IPC upheld; both lower courts' findings affirmed; appellant to surrender to bail bond and serve sentence.

key_quotes.text: The true rule is that in every case of this type the rule about the advisability of corroboration should be present to the mind of the judge... but corroboration can be dispensed with if... satisfied that it is safe to do so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains legal position on corroboration for rape prosecutrix testimony.

key_quotes.text: Whoever by force compels or by any deceitful means induces any person to go, from any place is said to abduct that person.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.362 IPC to hold appellant guilty of abduction.

key_quotes.text: Where a person on whom rape is committed is under 16 years of age, even consent is immaterial.
key_quotes.speaker: court
